title: Other outcome variables
text:
Behavioral measures

Donation
To assess consequential and impactful behavior, participants will be given the option to donate a monetary bonus to the American Geophysical Union (AGU), or keep it for themselves. The AGU was chosen because it is the leading scientific association for scientists working on climate change. Participants read following:


‚ÄúFor the next question, we would like you to have the opportunity to donate money to a non-profit or to keep it for yourself. Please decide how you would like to allocate $10 between yourself and the American Geophysical Union (AGU). The AGU is a non-profit, non-partisan scientific association. It is the largest scientific association in the area of climate change in the US, with over 15,000 scientist members. You can give all of the money to the AGU and keep none for yourself, or you can keep all the money for yourself and give none to AGU, or you can pick any split in between. Note: We will randomly select a subset of 100 participants and realize their choices.‚Äù

title: Other outcome variables
section: Normative perceptions & Willingness to be vulnerable
text:
Normative perceptions & Willingness to be vulnerable
[General consideration: normative perceptions, here, really are for the most part about scientists influence on public policy. It would make sense to have a more meaningful, less abstract name.]
Scales were adapted from Cologna et al. (2025), but slightly modified. For example, for the normative perception measure, we removed one item (‚ÄúClimate scientists should be more involved in the policy-making process‚Äù) as it was extremely close to the first item of the scale.
For the willingness to be vulnerable measure, we retained only one item, as the other two (‚ÄúHow much or little should governments rely on climate scientists‚Äô guidance when making decisions related to climate science?‚Äù and ‚ÄúHow much or little control do you want climate scientists to have on government decisions related to science?‚Äù) were very close conceptually to the normative perception measures.

normative_items <- tribble(
  ~Item, ~Response_Options,
  
# Normative Perceptions of Science and Society
  "To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?", "", 
  "Climate scientists should work closely with politicians to integrate scientific results into policy-making", 
    "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree",
  "Climate scientists should actively advocate for specific policies", 
    "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree",
  "Climate scientists should communicate their findings to politicians", 
    "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree",
  "Climate scientists should be more involved in the policy-making process", 
    "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree",
  "Climate scientists should communicate their findings to the general public", 
    "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree",
  "Climate scientists should remain independent from the policy-making process",

title: Now launched: Call for Collaboration
text:
ü§ù Collaborate with us!
The Strengthening Trust in Climate Scientists Megastudy is a collaborative research project to be run in the United States.
We invite researchers at any career stage‚Äîfrom students to principal investigators‚Äîas well as practitioners to submit intervention ideas.
Successful contributors will receive co-authorship in the primary publication arising from this project.
Interventions can be submitted by individuals or teams, with a maximum of two individuals per team. Each team may propose up to two interventions, which will be evaluated independently.


üîç What We‚Äôre Looking For
We are seeking short, text-based informational interventions that could increase trust in climate scientists.
The most promising interventions will be selected and tested in a megastudy‚Äîa large-scale online experiment designed for robust, replicable results.
üëâ Learn about submission rules and how to contribute on our Call for Collaborations page.
üìù Submit your intervention proposal via our designated submission survey.

üîó More information
For more information about the project and the team, visit our website.
üíå Questions? Email us anytime at
trustclimsci.megastudy@gmail.com

title: Research Design
text:
While trust in scientists is moderately high globally (Cologna et al. 2025), climate scientists have consistently been found to be less trusted than scientists from other fields and scientists in general (Druckman et al. 2024; Ghasemi et al. 2025; Schr√∏der 2023; Schug, Bilandzic, and Kinnebrock 2024). Lower trust in climate scientists could hamper societies‚Äô ability to address climate change, resulting in high personal and societal costs.
Strengthening trust in climate scientists matters: Across 55 countries, trust in climate scientists was the strongest predictor of belief in climate change and support for climate policy (Todorova et al. 2025).
Increasing trust in climate scientists may therefore be an important lever to accelerate climate action and strengthen societal resilience to climate change. There is currently only a small number of behavioral intervention studies on increasing trust in climate scientists. The Strengthening Trust in Climate Scientists Megastudy aims to fill this gap.

Show code
data <- SharedData$new(
  reviews_wide |>
    select(-intervention_id)
)



# get all details into row details
row_details <- function(index) {
  df <- data$data()        # extract underlying data frame
  row <- df[index, , drop = FALSE]

field <- function(label, value) {
  if (is.null(value) || is.na(value) || value == "") return(NULL)

  htmltools::tagList(
    # Header
    htmltools::div(
      style = "
        font-weight: 600;
        margin-top: 10px;
        color: #333;
        font-size: 0.95rem;
      ",
      label
    ),

    # Body text
    htmltools::pre(
      style = "
        margin-left: 12px;
        margin-top: 2px;
        margin-bottom: 10px;
        white-space: pre-wrap;
        word-wrap: break-word;
        overflow-wrap: break-word;
        font-size: 0.9rem;
      ",
      value
    )
  )
}

  htmltools::div(
    class = "details-box",
    field("Reviewer comments ‚Äî reviewer 1", row$reviewer_comments_1),
    field("Reviewer comments ‚Äî reviewer 2", row$reviewer_comments_2),
    field("Reviewer comments ‚Äî reviewer 3", row$reviewer_comments_3),
    field("Description", row$description),
    field("Stimulus", row$stimulus),
    field("Tested before?", row$tested), 
    field("Outcome previous test", row$outcome_previous_tests), 
    field("Effective?", row$effective), 
    field("Effect size", row$effect_size),
    field("Citation", row$citation),
    field("Comment", row$comment)
  )
}


reactable_data <- reactable(
  data,
  details = row_details,
  minRows = 10,
  columns = list(
    code_name = colDef(
      sticky = "left",
      style = list(borderRight = "1px solid #eee"),
      headerStyle = list(borderRight = "1px solid #eee")
    ),
    description = colDef(show = FALSE),
    stimulus = colDef(show = FALSE),
    reviewer_comments_1 = colDef(show = FALSE),
    reviewer_comments_2 = colDef(show = FALSE),
    reviewer_comments_3 = colDef(show = FALSE),
    tested = colDef(show = FALSE),
    outcome_previous_tests = colDef(show = FALSE),
    effective = colDef(show = FALSE),
    effect_size = colDef(show = FALSE),
    citation = colDef(show = FALSE), 
    comment = colDef(show = FALSE)
  ),
  searchable = TRUE,
  elementId = "reviews-table"
)

# produce table
shiny::fluidRow(
  shiny::column(
    4,
    filter_checkbox("intervention_content", "Content", data, ~intervention_content),
    filter_slider("overall_score", "Overall score", data, ~overall_score, width = "100%", round = 1),
    filter_checkbox("remove", "Remove", data, ~remove)
  ),
  shiny::column(
    8,
    reactable_data
  )
)
